text: let me show you how to make a
vinaigrette which is simply a blend of
oil with an acid such as vinegar and the
addition of a few seasonings what I like
to do is in a jar a blender or even a
ball you combine all of your ingredients
I'm gonna do it in a jar today a little
bit of mustard the mustard adds a great
flavor and it also helps to emulsify the
vinaigrette which means it holds it
together so that it's nice and creamy
instead of being separate the salt and
pepper will also go in at this time what
I like to do is start by dissolving the
mustard the salt and the pepper in your
vinegar the basic ratio for vinaigrette
is one part of vinegar to three parts of
oil I'm using a red wine vinegar but you
could use any kind of vinegar you like
or even an lemon or a lime for your acid
just because it's called the vinaigrette
doesn't mean you have to use vinegar and
olive oil three parts you could use any
kind of oil you want depending on what
you're making like if you're using
something Asian use a peanut oil you
could use corn oil walnut oil safflower
oil anything like that it's the ratio
that's important not the specific
amounts of each now I just shake it up
in this jar until it gets nice and
emulsified that's what I'm talking about
when I say emulsify it it's all nice and
creamy looking and cohesive you could
also add any kind of flavoring that you
want at this point just to vary the
flavor depending on what you want
herbs scallions garlic a little bit of
sugar a little bit of honey just add
herbs if you're using them right before
you use the dressing vinaigrette keeps
in the refrigerator for up to two weeks
if the oil solidifies let it come to
room temperature the oil and vinegar
will probably separate so just whisk or
shake to reimpose a fun
that was easy and just as delicious as
anything you'll find in the supermarket
hi guys thanks for watching this video
be sure to click here if you want to
subscribe and click over here if you
want to continue watching more great
